channel.title: Feminist Book Club
channel.description: This is an eight (8) week book club/discussion group. Girl power!

item.title: Week 8: Cultural Myths Behind Female Friendships
item.description:
Discussion Topics

This week’s must read:

  • “How to Be Friends with Another Woman” essay from Bad Feminist by Roxane Gay”

Additional content to read/watch:

item.title: Week 7: Reproductive Rights
item.description:
Discussion Topics

This week’s must read:

  • History of the Pill by Jonathan Eig

Additional content to read/watch:

item.title: Week 6: Gender Politics
item.description:
Discussion Topics

This week’s featured book:

  • Delusions of Gender by Cordelia Fine
  • “End of Men” by Hanna Rosin from the Atlantic
  • “I Don’t Belong Here” essay from Delusions of Gender by Cordelia Fine

Additional content to read/watch:

  • “The Myth of Male Decline” from the by Stephanie Coontz from the New York Times
  • “The Demise of Guys?” TED talk by Psychologist Philip Zimbardo
  • Sexual Politics by Kate Millett

item.title: Week 5: Women & The Workplace: Part 2
item.description:
Discussion Topics

  • What traits do you think women have that can help them in the workplace?
  • Do you think the trend to “give back” through one’s work is influnced by women?

This week’s must read:

  • Give and Take by Adam Grant

Additional content to read/watch:

  • “Feminist Hacker Barbie is just what our girls need” by Robert McMillan at Wired
  • Incoming salaries for recent MBA grads (men vs. women)

item.title: Week 4: Women & The Workplace: Part 1
item.description:
Discussion Topics

  • What do you see as being your biggest hurtle as a woman at work?
  • Do you think women hold themselves back at work?
  • Have you even been “mansplained” to?

This week’s must reads:

  • “Men Explain Things to Me” essay from Men Explain Things to Me by Rebecca Solnit
  • Lean In by Sheryl Sandberg

Additional content to read/watch:

  • Watch Sheryl Sanbderg’s TED Talk “Why We Have Too Few Women Leaders”
  • “Speaking While Female” Sheryl Sandberg and Adam Grand on Why Women Stay Quiet at Work from their “Women At Work” column in the New York Times
  • Read “Rethink What You ‘Know’ About High-Achieving Women” by Robin J. Ely, Pamela Stone, and Colleen Ammerman from the Harvard Business Review
  • Read “Mansplaning Mansplaing: A Man Explains Mansplaning” by Michael Mayberry from McSweeneys

item.title: Week 3: Violence Against Women in North America
item.description:
Discussion Topics

  • What is your definition of “rape culture”?

  • Do you feel we live is a society that teaches women to “not get raped” instead of teaching men “to not rape”?

  • Do you think our society encourages sexual violence against women?

  • What do you think could be done to help alleviate the problem of rape, revenge porn, and other forms of sexual violence in schools/colleges?

This week’s must read/watch:

  • “The Longest War” essay from Men Explain Things to Me by Rebecca Solnit. Originally published on TomDispatch.com
  • “The Careless Language of Sexual Violence” from Bad Feminist by Roxane Gay. Originally published on The Rumpus.com

Additional content to read/watch:

  • Watch Jackson Katz TED Talk Violence Against Women
  • Read “NYPD: Woman Walking In Clinton Hill Sexually Assaulted Twice in One Hour” from the Gothamist
  • Read “The Sexual Assault Crisis on American Campuses” from TIME
  • Read “Inside Anonymous’s Operation to Out Rehtaeh Parsons’s Rapists” from Vice
  • Read “Ma’lik Richmond, convicted in Stuebenville rape case, returns to football team”from NY Daily News
  • Read “In Steubenvile Rape Case, a Lesson for Adults” from the New York Times
  • Read “Vicious Assault Shakes Texas Town”from the New York Times
  • Read “Unpubished vandalism rampage inspired by Rolling Stone’s U.Va. rape story” from The Washington Post

item.title: Week 2: Women’s Rights are Human Rights
item.description:
This week we’ll be discusssing women’s rights from an international perspective.

Discussion Topics

  • Why are women and girls are still treated as second class citizens in most countries?
  • Why do you think there has been an out pouring of violence against women in 2nd and 3rd world countries in recent years?

This week’s featured book:

  • We Should All Be Feminists by Chiamana Ngozi Adiche

Additional content to read/watch:

  • Read/Watch Hillary Clinton’s speech “Women’s Rights are Human Rights” at the Fourth Women’s Confernce in Bejing, China in 1995
  • Watch Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s TED Talk
  • Watch Ziauddin Yousafzai’s TED Talk “My daughter, Malala”
  • Watch Malala Yousafzai’s Nobel Peace Prize Acceptance Speech
  • Read The Underground Girls of Kabul by Jenny Nordberg
  • Read “Indian Women Captured Fighting Off Sexual Attackers” from The Telegraph
  • Read “Indian Gang Rape: Six Men Charged with Murder” from The Guardian

item.title: Week 1:Definition of Feminism
item.description:
To kick off the series, we’ll be discusssing the what the word “feminism” means, why it’s often a loaded word, and why our generation has struggled to define the term for ourselves.

Discussion Topics

  • What is your personal definition of feminism?
  • Do you (or do you not) identify as a feminist?
  • Why do you think so many young women (including many female celebrities) are rejecting the term?

This week’s must reads:

  • “Feminism (n.):Plural” introduction by Roxane Gay from Bad Feminist
  • “Not My Mother’s Hose” essay by Courtney E. Martin from Click: When We Knew We Were Feminists, pages 89-93
  • “Word and Deed” essay by J. Courtney Sullivan from Click: When We Knew We Were Feminists, pages 191-197

Additional content to read/watch:

  • Watch Blogger Courtney Martin’s TED Talk on Reinventing Feminism
  • Watch Goodwill Ambassador for UN Women, Emma Watson’s Speech about gender equality. Here is the full transcript. Read more about her HeForShe initiative, which aims to get men and boys to pledge to join the feminist fight for gender equality.
